page.title: 04CECIL ALDIN
page.content: Purley was,for almost 20 years, the home of the famous sporting artist,Cecil Aldin.The village was the H.Q. of the South Berkshire Hunt,and Aldin moved there in 1913,when he became master of the foxhounds.Aldin was a leading newspaper illustrator and poster artist,who specialised in hunting scenes and dog illustrations. Two of his dogs,"Cracker" and "Micky" became famous animal models. A plaque in Purley church commemorates the death of Aldin's beloved son , Dudley, who fell in the First world war, aged 19.There is a 'Cecil Aldin Drive' in Purley ,and the barn in which Aldin stabled horses, as purchasing officer for the army in the first world war, can still be seen in the grounds of { {Trenthams Civil Engineering Firm}.
